explanation: The claim is not supported. The assignment response->total_size = connection->rp.rsp_write_position; is a write to shared program state (the response object) performed while holding the response mutex. Even though the code path then unlocks the mutex and initiates connection teardown, that write is not provably without observable effect: other threads or later code executed as part of the close/cleanup sequence may read response->total_size (or rely on it for logging/cleanup), and the write occurs while the mutex protects the object, which indicates intended cross-thread visibility. MISRA 2.2 (dead code) applies only where the operation can be shown to have no effect on program behaviour; here we cannot prove that the write cannot be observed. The FIXME/TODO comment in the source is an implementation note but does not itself prove the assignment is dead. Therefore the report that this statement violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is incorrect.
